prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 A1 CO4-3 A2 CO6-5
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A1 & A2 are close by in the sky with a 35' separation. For different CO transitions, we select the CO 6-5 transition for A2 (z=1.6780) in Baseband-1, and enter the same z to A1. The A1 CO 4-3 transition is then manually entered using the real z=0.7788 in Baseband-2. The other two available Basebands are used for additional continuum observations with manually selected frequencies.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See also Science Case). The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines, and also taken into account the strong recommendation to keep the `Total overhead' <30%. With the selected sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, the continuum of both targets will be marginally detected. The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (19.0 and 19.2 mJy at 500 micron for A1 and A2) to Band 6 (~1.3 mm). The requested angular resolution of 0.2" in B6 yields a linear scale of 1.5-1.7 kpc for z=0.8-1.7. We can test if these starburst-AGNs have similar extended molecular gas morphology. We can test if these starburst-AGNs have similar extended molecular gas morphology.
For the lines, the S/Ns are ~30 for A1 CO4-3 and ~20 for A2 CO 6-5 for a line width of 300 km/s. The `Total overheads' in this setting is XXX.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our selection of the line width over representative spectral window resolution is 8, allowing the measure of the shape of the line profile. Both the 2 basebands for CO lines and the 2 basebands for the continuum are well located in the central LO range. The two proposed lines are fully covered in the spectral windows.
For the continuum, we choose a spectral averaging of 16 elements at ~10km/s resolution across the 1.8 GHz bandwidth. This choice is made to avoid high data rate, as well as to allow higher S/N for continuum detection.

The requested angular resolution of 0.2" in B6 yields a linear scale of 1.5-1.7 kpc for z=0.8-1.7. We do not plan resolve the AGN from the host galaxy, as the former only lie in the central kpc of the galaxy. However, we decide to put a nominal largest scale of 2"(15-17 kpc). This value is still smaller than the theta_MRS = 3.4 for C36-5 at B6 and does not change the total time, because ACA is not needed. By making this choice, we could still get a S/N > 5 detection of the lines if they are spread over multiple beams.
This resolution allows measuring the size of both the CO gas (tracing SF) and that of the dust continuum (tracing the FIR emission). For both objects, CO velocity map can also be observed at this resolution. We will test if the host of these starburst-AGNs are extended as their SMG counterparts previously reported to have unordered gas kinematics in an 8-20kpc scale.

The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A1 & A2 are close by in the sky with a 35' separation. We select the CO(6-5) transition for A2 (z=1.6780) in Baseband-1, and enter the same nominal z for A1. The A1 CO(4-3) transition is then manually entered using the real z=0.7788 in Baseband-2. Basebands 3 and 4 are used for the continuum observations with manually selected frequencies in the other side band of the LO range.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See Science Case). Though we aim for a detection, with a proposed spectral resolution of 80 MHz, or ~93km/s the CO lines will spread over 4.3 spectral resolution elements for a line FWHM=400 km/s, allowing resolved line profile. The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines. At the requested sensitivity of 0.35 Jy, we will achieve a S/N of ~15 for A2 CO(6-5) and ~23 for A1 CO(4-3) at a line width of 400 km/s.
The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (19.0 and 19.2 mJy at 500 micron for A1 and A2) to Band 6 (~1.3 mm). To achieve a higher S/N for the dust continuum, we keep the 1.8 GHz bandwidth but choose a finer smoothed resolution of 7.813MHz, allowing binning of the spectra in phase 2. With this setting, the estimated S/N for continuum is ~16 for both A1 and A2.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 A3 CO6-5 A4 CO4-3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec and Sloan SDSS DR9, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A3 & A4 are close by in the sky with a 42' separation. For different CO transitions, we select the CO 6-5 transition for A3 (z=1.7560) in Baseband-1, and enter the same z to A4. The A4 CO 4-3 transition is then manually entered using the real z= 0.8267in Baseband-2. The other two available Basebands are used for additional continuum observations with manually selected frequencies.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See also Science Case). The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines, and also taken into account the strong recommendation to keep the `Total overhead' <30%. With the selected sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, the continuum of the 2 targets will be detected for both A3 and A4 (>= 3 sigma). The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (50.9 and 16.5 mJy at 500 micron for A3 and A4) to Band 6 (~1.3 mm). The requested angular resolution of 0.2" in B6 yields a linear scale of 1.5-1.7 kpc for z=0.8-1.7. We can test if these starburst-AGNs have similar extended molecular gas morphology.
For the lines, the S/Ns are ~20 for A3 CO6-5 and ~16 for A4 CO 4-3 for a line width of 300 km/s. The `Total overheads' in this setting is XXX.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our selection of the line width over representative spectral window resolution is 8, allowing the measure of the shape of the line profile. Both the 2 basebands for CO lines and the 2 basebands for the continuum are well located in the central LO range. The two proposed lines are fully covered in the spectral windows.
For the continuum, we choose a spectral averaging of 16 elements at ~10km/s resolution across the 1.8 GHz bandwidth. This choice is made to avoid high data rate, as well as to allow higher S/N for continuum detection.

The requested angular resolution of 0.2" in B6 yields a linear scale of 1.5-1.7 kpc for z=0.8-1.7. We do not plan resolve the AGN from the host galaxy, as the former only lie in the central kpc of the galaxy. However, we decide to put a nominal largest scale of 2"(15-17 kpc). This value is still smaller than the theta_MRS = 3.4 for C36-5 at B6 and does not change the total time, because ACA is not needed. By making this choice, we could still get a S/N > 5 detection of the lines if they are spread over multiple beams.
This resolution allows measuring the size of both the CO gas (tracing SF) and that of the dust continuum (tracing the FIR emission). For both objects, CO velocity map can also be observed at this resolution. We will test if the host of these starburst-AGNs are extended as their SMG counterparts previously reported to have unordered gas kinematics in an 8-20kpc scale.

The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec and Sloan SDSS DR9, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A3 & A4 are close by in the sky with a 40' separation. We select the CO(6-5) transition for A3 (z=1.7560) in Baseband-1, and enter the same nominal z for A4. The A4 CO(4-3) transition is then manually entered using the real z=0.8267 in Baseband-2. Basebands 3 and 4 are used for the continuum observations with manually selected frequencies in the other side band of the LO range.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See Science Case). Though we aim for a detection, with a proposed spectral resolution of 80 MHz, or ~95km/s the CO lines will spread over 4.2 spectral resolution elements for a line FWHM=400 km/s, allowing resolved line profile. The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines. At the requested sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, we will achieve a S/N of ~16 for A4 CO(6-5) and ~21 for A3 CO(4-3) at a line width of 400 km/s.
The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (50.9 and 16.5 mJy at 500 micron for A3 and A4) to Band 6 (~1.3 mm). To achieve a higher S/N for the dust continuum, we keep the 1.8 GHz bandwidth but choose a finer smoothed resolution of 7.813MHz, allowing binning of the spectra in phase 2. With this setting, the The estimated S/N for continuum is ~40 for A3 and ~14 for A4.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B4 A1 CO2-1 A2 CO3-2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A1 & A2 are close by in the sky with a 35' separation. For different CO transitions, we select the CO 6-5 transition for A2 (z=1.6780) in Baseband-1, and enter the same z to A1. The A1 CO 4-3 transition is then manually entered using the real z=0.7788 in Baseband-2. The other two available Basebands are used for additional continuum observations with manually selected frequencies.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See also Science Case). The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines, and also taken into account the strong recommendation to keep the `Total overhead' <30%. With the selected sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, the continuum of both targets will be marginally detected. The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (19.0 and 19.2 mJy at 500 micron for A1 and A2) to Band 6 (~1.3 mm). The requested angular resolution of 0.2" in B6 yields a linear scale of 1.5-1.7 kpc for z=0.8-1.7. We can test if these starburst-AGNs have similar extended molecular gas morphology. We can test if these starburst-AGNs have similar extended molecular gas morphology.
For the lines, the S/Ns are ~30 for A1 CO4-3 and ~20 for A2 CO 6-5 for a line width of 300 km/s. The `Total overheads' in this setting is XXX.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our selection of the line width over representative spectral window resolution is 4, allowing the measure of the shape of the line profile. Both the 2 basebands for CO lines and the 2 basebands for the continuum are well located in the B4 freqency range. The two proposed lines are fully covered in the spectral windows.
For the continuum, we choose a spectral averaging of 16 elements at ~17km/s resolution across the 1.8 GHz bandwidth. This choice is made to avoid high data rate, as well as to allow higher S/N for continuum detection.

The requested angular resolution of 0.3" in B4 yields a linear scale of 2.3-2.6 kpc for z=0.8-1.7. We do not plan resolve the AGN from the host galaxy, as the former only lie in the central kpc of the galaxy. However, we decide to put a nominal largest scale of 3" (23-26 kpc). This value is still smaller than the theta_MRS = 5.2 for C36-5 at B4 and does not change the total time, because ACA is not needed. By making this choice, we could still get a S/N > 3 detection of the lines if they are spread over multiple beams.
This resolution allows measuring the size of both the CO gas (tracing SF) and that of the dust continuum (tracing the FIR emission). For both objects, CO velocity map can also be observed at this resolution. We will test if the host of these starburst-AGNs are extended as their SMG counterparts previously reported to have unordered gas kinematics in an 8-20kpc scale.

The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A1 & A2 are close by in the sky with a 35' separation. We select the CO(2-1) transition for A1 (z=0.7788) in Baseband-1, and enter the same nominal z for A1. The A2 CO(3-2) transition is then manually entered using the real z=1.6780 in Baseband-2. Basebands 3 and 4 are used for the continuum observations with manually selected frequencies in the other side band of the LO range.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See Science Case). Though we aim for a detection, with a proposed spectral resolution of 50 MHz, or ~115km/s the CO lines will spread over 3.5 spectral resolution elements for a line FWHM=400 km/s, allowing resolved line profile. The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines. At the requested sensitivity of 0.3 mJy, we will achieve a S/N of ~7 for A2 CO(3-2) and ~18 for A1 CO(2-1) at a line width of 400 km/s.
The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (19.0 and 19.2 mJy at 500 micron for A1 and A2) to Band 4 (~3 mm). To achieve a higher S/N for the dust continuum, we keep the 1.8 GHz bandwidth but choose a finer smoothed resolution of 7.813MHz, allowing binning of the spectra in phase 2. The estimated S/N for continuum is ~18 for both A1 and A2.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B4 A3 CO3-2 A4 CO2-1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec and Sloan SDSS DR9, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A3 & A4 are close by in the sky with a 42' separation. For different CO transitions, we select the CO 6-5 transition for A3 (z=1.7560) in Baseband-1, and enter the same z to A4. The A4 CO 4-3 transition is then manually entered using the real z= 0.8267in Baseband-2. The other two available Basebands are used for additional continuum observations with manually selected frequencies.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See also Science Case). The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines, and also taken into account the strong recommendation to keep the `Total overhead' <30%. With the selected sensitivity of 0.35 mJy, the continuum of the 2 targets will be detected for both A3 and A4 (>= 3 sigma). The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (50.9 and 16.5 mJy at 500 micron for A3 and A4) to Band 6 (~1.3 mm). The requested angular resolution of 0.2" in B6 yields a linear scale of 1.5-1.7 kpc for z=0.8-1.7. We can test if these starburst-AGNs have similar extended molecular gas morphology.
For the lines, the S/Ns are ~20 for A3 CO6-5 and ~16 for A4 CO 4-3 for a line width of 300 km/s. The `Total overheads' in this setting is XXX.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our selection of the line width over representative spectral window resolution is 4, allowing the measure of the shape of the line profile. The 2 basebands for the continuum are well located in the B4 LO window. The A4 CO(2-1) line is fully covered by the spectral window. We manually adjusted the central frequency of A3 CO(3-2) from 125.47 GHz to 126.10 GHz so that this line is fully covered in the spectral window.
For the continuum, we choose a spectral averaging of 16 elements at ~17km/s resolution across the 1.8 GHz bandwidth. This choice is made to avoid high data rate, as well as to allow higher S/N for continuum detection.

The requested angular resolution of 0.3" in B4 yields a linear scale of 2.3-2.6 kpc for z=0.8-1.7. We do not plan resolve the AGN from the host galaxy, as the former only lie in the central kpc of the galaxy. However, we decide to put a nominal largest scale of 3" (23-26 kpc). This value is still smaller than the theta_MRS = 5.2 for C36-5 at B4 and does not change the total time, because ACA is not needed. By making this choice, we could still get a S/N > 3 detection of the lines if they are spread over multiple beams.
This resolution allows measuring the size of both the CO gas (tracing SF) and that of the dust continuum (tracing the FIR emission). For both objects, CO velocity map can also be observed at this resolution. We will test if the host of these starburst-AGNs are extended as their SMG counterparts previously reported to have unordered gas kinematics in an 8-20kpc scale.

The two targets have precise spectroscopic redshifts from MMT Hectospec and Sloan SDSS DR9, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. By observing 2 close-by sources per Science Goal, we increase the efficiency per overhead. A3 & A4 are close by in the sky with a 40' separation. We select the CO(2-1) transition for A4 (z=0.8267) in Baseband-1, and enter the same nominal z for A4. The A3 CO(3-2) transition is then manually entered using the real z=1.7560 in Baseband-2. Basebands 3 and 4 are used for the continuum observations with manually selected frequencies in the other side band of the LO range.
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) for a given sensitivity. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from Fig. 2, using FIR luminosity as tracer for CO line luminosity (See Science Case). Though we aim for a detection, with a proposed spectral resolution of 50 MHz, or ~119km/s the CO lines will spread over 3.4 spectral resolution elements for a line FWHM=400 km/s, allowing resolved line profile. The chosen sensitivity is driven by the lower S/N of the 2 selected CO lines. At the requested sensitivity of 0.3mJy, we will achieve a S/N of ~8 for A3 CO(3-2) and ~13 for A4 CO(2-1) at a line width of 400 km/s.
The continuum values are derived by extrapolating the detected Herschel-HerMES fluxes (50.9 and 16.5 mJy at 500 micron for A3 and A4) to Band 4 (~3 mm). To achieve a higher S/N for the dust continuum, we keep the 1.8 GHz bandwidth but choose a finer smoothed resolution of 7.813MHz, allowing binning of the spectra in phase 2. The estimated S/N for continuum is ~40 for A3 and ~14 for A4.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Starburst-AGNs are identified by their simultaneously powerful X-ray and FIR dust emissions. Such exceptionally X-ray & FIR luminous objects are very rare and only detectable with large area surveys. We searched the 11 deg sq XMM-LSS field and found 4 starburst-AGNs, two at z~0.8 and two at z~1.7, with LX(2-10 keV)=(1.4-4.4)10^44 erg/s, L(FIR)=(0.11-1.7)10^13 Lsun, and T(dust)= 22-38 K. We propose to study the ISM in these starburst-AGNs in Band 4 and 6 via CO emissions and dust continuum. The goals are to study the ISM mass, accurate SFR, and gas consumption time scale. The updated L'(CO)-L(FIR) relation will also be used to test if AGN-starbursts are more gas depleted than normal starbursts.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
